thread.title: Arkansas-Auburn clash not what it seemed in August
thread.title_full: Arkansas-Auburn clash not what it seemed in August

title: Arkansas-Auburn clash not what it seemed in August
text:
Arkansas-Auburn clash not what it seemed in August Nate Allen, nallensports@att.net 2:27 p.m. CDT October 23, 2015 Auburn head coach Gus Malzahn congratulates Auburn wide receiver Ryan Davis after a touchdown during the second half against Kentucky. (Photo: AP) 5 CONNECT 1 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
FAYETTEVILLE — Back in August, today’s Arkansas vs. Auburn SEC West game surely was destined for CBS’s afternoon SEC game of the week or ESPN’s SEC primetime game. 
Now with thunderstorms forecast, it seems the Weather Channel might have the most interest in today’s game at Reynolds Razorback Stadium relegated to an 11 a.m. kickoff on the SEC Network. 
Coach Gus Malzahn’s Auburn Tigers and coach Bret Bielema’s Razorbacks obviously have not fulfilled the projections of their long-gone August preseason AP Top 25 rankings. Auburn in August ranked sixth and Arkansas 18th. 
However, both have played better in October than September, when the Razorbacks were consecutively upset in Little Rock and Fayetteville by Toledo and Texas Tech and lost in SEC overtime to Texas A&M at the Dallas Cowboys’ AT&T Stadium. Meanwhile, in Auburn, Ala., Auburn was lucky to escape lower FCS division Jacksonville State in overtime and lost SEC games, 45-21 and 17-9 at LSU and in Auburn to Mississippi State. 
For October, including two weeks ago an open date, Auburn is 2-0, beating San Jose State nonconference and winning 30-27 on Oct. 15 a SEC game at Kentucky. 
Arkansas, coming off an open date week, on Oct. 3 beat SEC rival Tennessee, 24-20 in Knoxville, Tenn. and Oct. 10 in Tuscaloosa, Ala. led nationally No. 8 Alabama, the reigning SEC champion, 7-3 into the third quarter before finally losing, 27-14. 
Both teams are starting to feel better about themselves which makes both teams wary of the other. 
“It was a good win last game versus Kentucky and we have a little momentum an starting to play solid football,” Malzahn, the Arkansas native and former Arkansas champion high school coach at Hughes, Shiloh Christian and Springdale the 2006 Razorbacks offensive coordinator, said. “We certainly have our work cut out for us against a very good Arkansas team. Their record is deceiving. They have played some very good opponents (three of the four, Toledo, Texas A&M and Alabama, defeating Arkansas rank in the AP Top 25 with Texas Tech also receiving AP votes) and had a chance to win a couple of those.” 
Bielema calls his Razorbacks a better team now than at the season’s outset and in turn praises Auburn. 
“Auburn is a good football team,” Bielema said. “Obviously that has had a lot of success with Coach Malzahn and everything he brings to the table. They bring a lot of the same things we have seen in the past but offensively (changing quarterbacks from junior Jeremy Johnson to redshirt freshman Sean White) they bring a few more wrinkles and defensively the change they had in coordinators (hiring Will Muschamp, the former Florida head Coach and before that a renowned defensive coordinator at LSU and Texas) brought new schemes.” 
Johnson was highly touted as last year’s Auburn backup to departed senior Nick Marshall but was benched after three games this season having thrown more interceptions, six, than touchdowns five. 
White has thrown one interception against zero touchdowns but has moved the Tigers more efficiently. 
“I think their quarterback has played well for them and he’s been a good manager of the game,” Arkansas defensive coordinator Robb Smith said. “He’s made throws when he needed to.” 
Auburn was lavished preseason love primarily on the hiring of Muschamp to masterminded a defense that finished miserably in 2014 as those 8-5 Tigers lost four of their last five. Offensively pundits, always enamored of Malzahn’s Hurry-UP-No-Huddle Spread offense, were sold on the pass-catch potential of Johnson, impressive starting (12 of 16 for 243 yards with two touchdowns and zero picks) the first half against Arkansas last year, and receiver Duke Williams (45 catches for 730 yards and 5 touchdowns last season). 
Williams has been kicked off the team, and Johnson benched, while even Muschamp overnight couldn’t turn a leaky defense into a great one. 
But the Tigers defensively are improving. And Malzahn, Bielema remarked, adapts well to his offensive personnel. Unlike his pass prolific Springdale and Shiloh Christian days, Malzahn all three of his Auburn head coaching seasons has geared his Spread offense more to the run than the pass. 
Bielema from his seven years coaching Wisconsin into Year Three at Arkansas always has geared to the run even with senior quarterback Brandon Allen dramatically improving as a passer. 
The Razorbacks, with tailback Alex Collins exceeding 150 yards for three consecutive games, were running in high gear until meeting Alabama at high Crimson Tide on Oct. 10. 
Though today’s game could come down to a pass, as close games between run-oriented teams often do, whoever best runs the ball and stops the run seems most apt to run out of Reynolds Razorback Stadium victorious. 5 CONNECT 1 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE Read or Share this story: http://www.baxterbulletin.com/story/sports/2015/10/23/arkansas-auburn-clash-seemed-august/74471620/ TOP VIDEOS
